Since it's recessive, neither parent is showing the disease themselves because they don't have two copies of the mutated gene. Now, neither Betsy nor Boopsy, their children, are anemic. Autosomal recessive would mean each parent contributes a B allele for the child to receive, making them Bb. But if the condition is autosomal recessive, then to express the disease, you need two copies of the defective allele, like BB or Bb? Wait, no—wait, actually, in recessive conditions, only when you have two copies does the disease manifest. So if someone has one defective allele, they don't get sick. So if both parents have Bb (since they have one substitution), then their children could have: - BB (if both give B)
- Bb (if one gives B and the other gives b) In terms of the autosomal recessive condition, only those who have two copies (BB) would be affected. Bb individuals would be carriers but wouldn't have the disease yet. A. Only one parent can pass the disorder to the children

B. Both parents will definitely pass the disorder to their children

C. Both children inherited a different form of anemia that is not detectable at their current age.

E. The children cannot be carriers since they are not anemic.

F. The children have a 50% chance of being carriers and a 25% chance of being affected.

G. The disorder can only be inherited from the mother.

H. Neither of the parents can pass the disorder to their children

I. The children are anemic but show no symptoms due to a modifier gene.

J. Each child will inherit the disorder, but it will remain dormant until adulthood.

Answer with only a single letter. Answer:<|im_end|>
